flashcard_content:
#### Domain
Domains are the broadest taxonomic groupings of organisms, classified based on characteristics such as cell structure and chemistry. There are three domains: Bacteria, Archaea, and Eukarya.

:p What are the three main domains of living organisms?
??x
The three main domains of living organisms are Bacteria, Archaea, and Eukarya.
x??
input_text_excerpt: Scientists often refer to this system as tax - onomy. Not only does taxonomy provide official names for every plant and animal, but it also  helps scientists understand how living creatures are relate...

chapter_title: Just name it Showing off your genius about the species
flashcard_content:
#### Kingdom
Kingdoms group organisms based on developmental characteristics and whether they can make their own food. There is debate about the exact number, but there are generally five or six kingdoms: Animalia, Plantae, Fungi, Protista, Monera, and sometimes Chromista.

:p How many kingdoms are generally recognized by scientists?
??x
Scientists generally recognize five or six kingdoms: Animalia, Plantae, Fungi, Protista, Monera, and occasionally Chromista.
x??
input_text_excerpt: Scientists often refer to this system as tax - onomy. Not only does taxonomy provide official names for every plant and animal, but it also  helps scientists understand how living creatures are relate...

chapter_title: Just name it Showing off your genius about the species
flashcard_content:
#### Phylum
Phyla group organisms within a kingdom based on general characteristics. There are 36 phyla in the Animal Kingdom alone.

:p How many phyla exist in the Animal Kingdom?
??x
There are 36 phyla in the Animal Kingdom.
x??
input_text_excerpt: Scientists often refer to this system as tax - onomy. Not only does taxonomy provide official names for every plant and animal, but it also  helps scientists understand how living creatures are relate...

chapter_title: Just name it Showing off your genius about the species
flashcard_content:
#### Class
Classes further divide organisms of the same phylum by similar characteristics. For example, humans and other primates belong to the class Mammalia, while birds belong to Aves.

:p What is an example of a class within the Animal Kingdom?
??x
An example of a class within the Animal Kingdom is Mammalia, which includes humans.
x??
input_text_excerpt: Scientists often refer to this system as tax - onomy. Not only does taxonomy provide official names for every plant and animal, but it also  helps scientists understand how living creatures are relate...

chapter_title: Just name it Showing off your genius about the species
flashcard_content:
#### Order
Orders separate organisms based on the characteristics of major groups within their class. For instance, primates (humans, apes, and monkeys) are part of the order Primata.

:p What is an example of an order in the Animal Kingdom?
??x
An example of an order in the Animal Kingdom is Primata, which includes humans, apes, and monkeys.
x??
input_text_excerpt: Scientists often refer to this system as tax - onomy. Not only does taxonomy provide official names for every plant and animal, but it also  helps scientists understand how living creatures are relate...

chapter_title: Just name it Showing off your genius about the species
flashcard_content:
#### Family
Families further divide organisms within the same order by similar characteristics. Humans are part of the family Hominidae.

:p What is an example of a family within the Primate order?
??x
An example of a family within the Primate order is Hominidae, which includes humans.
x??
input_text_excerpt: Scientists often refer to this system as tax - onomy. Not only does taxonomy provide official names for every plant and animal, but it also  helps scientists understand how living creatures are relate...

chapter_title: Just name it Showing off your genius about the species
flashcard_content:
#### Genus
Genera group two or more closely related species with unique body structures into a single genus. Humans and gorillas belong to different genera: Homo for humans and Gorilla for gorillas.

:p What is an example of a genus in the Animal Kingdom?
??x
An example of a genus in the Animal Kingdom is Homo, which includes modern humans.
x??
input_text_excerpt: Scientists often refer to this system as tax - onomy. Not only does taxonomy provide official names for every plant and animal, but it also  helps scientists understand how living creatures are relate...

chapter_title: Just name it Showing off your genius about the species
flashcard_content:
#### Species
Species are the most specific taxonomic level. Organisms within the same species share very similar characteristics. For example, all chimpanzees and bonobos belong to the same species Pan troglodytes.

:p What is an example of a species in the Animal Kingdom?
??x
An example of a species in the Animal Kingdom is Pan troglodytes, which includes both chimpanzees and bonobos.
x??

#### Scientific Naming of Organisms
Background context explaining how organisms are named using binomial nomenclature. The name consists of a genus and species, both written in italics with the genus capitalized and the species in lowercase.

:p What is the scientific naming system for organisms?
??x
The scientific naming system for organisms uses a two-word format: the genus (capitalized) followed by the species (lowercase). Both are italicized. For example, humans are named Homo sapiens.

Background context explaining that the human body consists of several major systems working together to maintain life.

:p What are the main components of the nervous system?

The main components of the nervous system include the cerebrum, cerebellum, medulla, spinal cord, and nerves. These parts work together to receive, process, and respond to physical stimuli.

Background context explaining how these systems deliver oxygenated blood and nutrients while removing waste.

:p What are the main components of the cardiovascular system?

The main components of the cardiovascular system include the heart, arteries, veins, capillaries, and blood. These components work together to deliver oxygenated blood and nutrients from the heart to the rest of the body.

The main components of the respiratory system include the nose, nasal cavity, trachea, and lungs. These parts work together to inhale air, use the oxygen in the air to release energy, and exhale carbon dioxide.

Background context explaining how these systems break down food into absorbable substances and eliminate waste.

The main components of the digestive system include the mouth, esophagus, stomach, and intestines. These organs work together to break down food into smaller substances that can be absorbed by the body.

Background context explaining how muscles allow for movement.

The three types of muscles in the muscular system are smooth, cardiac, and skeletal. Smooth muscles line internal organs; cardiac muscles make up the heart; and skeletal muscles move bones.

input_text_excerpt: 204  PART 4  Examining General Science under a MicroscopeJust name it: Showing off your genius about the species Each organism is given a scientific name that consists of two words (usually derived fr...

flashcard_content:
---
#### Nervous System Overview
The nervous system controls and coordinates the body's activities, including movement, sensation, thinking, and behavior. It is composed of two main parts: the central nervous system (CNS) and the peripheral nervous system (PNS).

- **Central Nervous System**: Includes the brain and spinal cord.
- **Peripheral Nervous System**: Consists of all other neurons that are not part of the CNS.

The brain has several key regions:
- **Cerebrum**: Responsible for higher functions like thinking, hearing, seeing, and others.
- **Cerebellum**: Manages balance and muscle coordination.
- **Medulla**: Handles involuntary actions such as heartbeat.
- **Spinal Cord**: Acts as a highway for nerve impulses between the brain and organs.

:p What are the main components of the nervous system?
??x
The central nervous system (CNS) includes the brain and spinal cord, while the peripheral nervous system (PNS) encompasses all other neurons. The CNS has specific regions like the cerebrum, cerebellum, medulla, and spinal cord.
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 10  General Science and Life Science   205Your nervous system is at the wheel, controlling everything that happens in your body. Your car- diovascular system pumps blood to spread oxygen to al...

flashcard_content:
#### Functions of the Nervous System
The nervous system is responsible for controlling various bodily functions through chemical and electrical signals. These functions can be either voluntary or involuntary:
- **Voluntary actions**: Actions that require active choice, like eating or scratching an itch.
- **Involuntary actions**: Automatic processes such as breathing and blood pumping.

:p What distinguishes voluntary from involuntary actions in the nervous system?
??x
Voluntary actions involve conscious decisions (e.g., eating or scratching), whereas involuntary actions are automatic (e.g., breathing or heartbeat).
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 10  General Science and Life Science   205Your nervous system is at the wheel, controlling everything that happens in your body. Your car- diovascular system pumps blood to spread oxygen to al...

flashcard_content:
#### The Brain's Regions
The brain has distinct regions that perform specific functions:
- **Cerebrum**: Mainly responsible for cognitive processes, sensory perception, and voluntary motor control.
- **Cerebellum**: Manages coordination and balance.
- **Medulla**: Controls involuntary actions like heartbeat.

:p Which part of the brain is primarily involved in thinking and hearing?
??x
The cerebrum is primarily involved in thinking, hearing, seeing, and other cognitive processes.
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 10  General Science and Life Science   205Your nervous system is at the wheel, controlling everything that happens in your body. Your car- diovascular system pumps blood to spread oxygen to al...

flashcard_content:
#### Central Nervous System Components
The central nervous system includes:
- **Cerebrum**: Controls higher functions like thought and perception.
- **Cerebellum**: Manages coordination and balance.
- **Medulla**: Regulates involuntary actions such as heartbeat.

:p What is the function of the medulla in the CNS?
??x
The medulla in the central nervous system regulates involuntary actions, including the control of the heartbeat.
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 10  General Science and Life Science   205Your nervous system is at the wheel, controlling everything that happens in your body. Your car- diovascular system pumps blood to spread oxygen to al...

flashcard_content:
#### Peripheral Nervous System
The peripheral nervous system includes all neurons outside the brain and spinal cord. It connects the CNS to various parts of the body.

:p What does the peripheral nervous system connect?
??x
The peripheral nervous system connects the central nervous system (brain and spinal cord) to other parts of the body, facilitating communication between them.
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 10  General Science and Life Science   205Your nervous system is at the wheel, controlling everything that happens in your body. Your car- diovascular system pumps blood to spread oxygen to al...

flashcard_content:
#### Cardiovascular System Overview
The cardiovascular system is responsible for circulating blood throughout the body. It includes:
- **Heart**: A four-chambered organ that pumps blood.
- **Blood Vessels**: Including arteries, veins, and capillaries.

:p What are the main components of the cardiovascular system?
??x
The main components of the cardiovascular system include the heart, which is a four-chambered organ, and blood vessels such as arteries, veins, and capillaries.
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 10  General Science and Life Science   205Your nervous system is at the wheel, controlling everything that happens in your body. Your car- diovascular system pumps blood to spread oxygen to al...

flashcard_content:
#### Heart Structure and Function
The heart has four chambers: two atria and two ventricles. The atria collect blood, while the ventricles pump it out. Valves ensure one-way blood flow.

:p How does the heart structure facilitate efficient blood circulation?
??x
The heart's structure facilitates efficient blood circulation by having four chambers (two atria and two ventricles) that work together to collect and pump blood. Valves ensure one-way blood flow, preventing backflow.
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 10  General Science and Life Science   205Your nervous system is at the wheel, controlling everything that happens in your body. Your car- diovascular system pumps blood to spread oxygen to al...

flashcard_content:
#### Blood Vessels
- **Arteries**: Large, thick-walled vessels that carry oxygenated blood away from the heart.
- **Capillaries**: Tiny vessels where exchange of substances occurs.
- **Veins**: Thinner walls and smaller diameter, carrying deoxygenated blood back to the heart.

:p What is the primary function of capillaries in the circulatory system?
??x
The primary function of capillaries in the circulatory system is to facilitate the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, carbon dioxide, and waste between the bloodstream and tissues.
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 10  General Science and Life Science   205Your nervous system is at the wheel, controlling everything that happens in your body. Your car- diovascular system pumps blood to spread oxygen to al...

flashcard_content:
#### Blood Composition
Blood consists of:
- **Plasma**: Liquid component.
- **Cells**: Red blood cells (carry oxygen), white blood cells (fight infection), platelets (cause clotting).

:p What are the main components of human blood?
??x
The main components of human blood include plasma, which is the liquid part, and cells such as red blood cells that carry oxygen, white blood cells that fight infections, and platelets that cause clotting.
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 10  General Science and Life Science   205Your nervous system is at the wheel, controlling everything that happens in your body. Your car- diovascular system pumps blood to spread oxygen to al...

flashcard_content:
#### Blood Types
There are four main blood types: A, B, AB, and O. Each type can be positive or negative.

:p What determines the different blood types?
??x
Blood types are determined by specific antigens on red blood cells. The four main types are A, B, AB, and O. The positive or negative designation refers to the presence or absence of the Rh factor.
x??

---

chapter_title: Damage control through the integumentary system
flashcard_content:
#### Ligaments and Tendons
Background context: Ligaments and tendons are crucial components of your musculoskeletal system. They work together to facilitate movement by connecting different parts of your body.

:p What is the difference between ligaments and tendons?
??x
Ligaments join bones, while tendons connect muscle tissue to bones or other structures.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 208  PART 4  Examining General Science under a MicroscopeLigaments and tendons help your bones move so you can move. Ligaments  join the bones (think  of them like rubber bands), while tendons  connec...

chapter_title: Damage control through the integumentary system
flashcard_content:
#### Endocrine System Overview
Background context: The endocrine system uses hormones to regulate various bodily functions including reproduction, growth, sleep, mood, and more. Hormones act as messengers between glands and organs.

:p What role do hormones play in the endocrine system?
??x
Hormones serve as chemical messengers that control and coordinate numerous physiological processes, such as metabolism, growth, and development.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 208  PART 4  Examining General Science under a MicroscopeLigaments and tendons help your bones move so you can move. Ligaments  join the bones (think  of them like rubber bands), while tendons  connec...

chapter_title: Damage control through the integumentary system
flashcard_content:
#### Lymphatic System: Fighting Infections
Background context: The lymphatic system includes fluids like lymph, which contains white blood cells to fight infections. It is part of the immune system.

:p What are bacteria and viruses?
??x
Bacteria are single-celled organisms that can cause illnesses such as pneumonia and staph infections, while viruses, like colds and HIV, also lead to diseases.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 208  PART 4  Examining General Science under a MicroscopeLigaments and tendons help your bones move so you can move. Ligaments  join the bones (think  of them like rubber bands), while tendons  connec...

chapter_title: Damage control through the integumentary system
flashcard_content:
#### Antibiotics vs Viruses
Background context: Antibiotics are effective against bacterial infections but not viral ones. Viral diseases often require other forms of prevention, such as vaccines.

:p How do antibiotics work?
??x
Antibiotics target and kill bacteria by interfering with their cell walls or preventing protein synthesis, thereby treating bacterial infections.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 208  PART 4  Examining General Science under a MicroscopeLigaments and tendons help your bones move so you can move. Ligaments  join the bones (think  of them like rubber bands), while tendons  connec...

chapter_title: Damage control through the integumentary system
flashcard_content:
#### Vaccinations: Preventing Diseases
Background context: Vaccines help the immune system recognize specific pathogens before they cause illness. This prevents diseases from spreading within the body.

:p What is a vaccine?
??x
A vaccine introduces an antigen (a component of a pathogen) into the body to stimulate an immune response, teaching the immune system how to fight off future infections.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 208  PART 4  Examining General Science under a MicroscopeLigaments and tendons help your bones move so you can move. Ligaments  join the bones (think  of them like rubber bands), while tendons  connec...

chapter_title: Damage control through the integumentary system
flashcard_content:
#### Human Body: A Balancing Act
Background context: The human body constantly strives for homeostasis. Some diseases are preventable through lifestyle and diet choices, while others may be genetically inherited or caused by pathogens.

:p What are vectors?
??x
Vectors are organisms that transmit diseases to humans, such as mosquitoes, rats, and ticks.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 208  PART 4  Examining General Science under a MicroscopeLigaments and tendons help your bones move so you can move. Ligaments  join the bones (think  of them like rubber bands), while tendons  connec...

chapter_title: Damage control through the integumentary system
flashcard_content:
#### George Washington's Inoculation Order
Background context: General George Washington ordered his troops to be inoculated against smallpox during the Revolutionary War. This early form of vaccination was effective in preventing severe cases.

:p Why did General Washington order smallpox inoculations?
??x
Washington ordered smallpox inoculations to prevent soldiers from getting a more serious version of the disease, which had previously affected about 5,000 Continental soldiers.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 208  PART 4  Examining General Science under a MicroscopeLigaments and tendons help your bones move so you can move. Ligaments  join the bones (think  of them like rubber bands), while tendons  connec...

chapter_title: Damage control through the integumentary system
flashcard_content:
#### Modern Military Vaccinations
Background context: Troops are tested for immunity upon arrival at basic training and receive vaccinations if necessary. These include protection against various diseases like flu, chickenpox, smallpox, anthrax, etc.

:p What types of vaccines do modern troops receive?
??x
Modern troops receive vaccinations to protect against a variety of diseases, such as the flu, chickenpox, smallpox, and anthrax.
x??

---
input_text_excerpt: 208  PART 4  Examining General Science under a MicroscopeLigaments and tendons help your bones move so you can move. Ligaments  join the bones (think  of them like rubber bands), while tendons  connec...

chapter_title: Continuing the species through the reproductive system. Digging through Plant Physiology
flashcard_content:
#### Integumentary System Protection
The integumentary system includes your skin, nails, hair, sweat glands, sebaceous glands (oil-producing), and ceruminous glands (earwax). These components protect you from injuries, dehydration, and ensure that vitamin D production occurs. Vitamin D synthesis is triggered by exposure to sunlight.
:p What does the integumentary system protect you from?
??x
The integumentary system protects you from physical damage such as cuts or scrapes, prevents excessive water loss through your skin, and helps in producing vitamin D when exposed to sunlight.
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 10  General Science and Life Science   209Damage control through the   integumentary system The integumentary system  protects you from getting scuffed up, losing all the water in your body,  ...

chapter_title: Continuing the species through the reproductive system. Digging through Plant Physiology
flashcard_content:
#### Reproductive System Functionality
Reproduction involves the interaction of sex organs both internally (testes, ovaries, fallopian tubes, uterus) and externally. The process requires a sperm from a male to fertilize an egg from a female. If successful, this leads to the formation of a zygote that can develop into a fetus.
:p How does human reproduction occur?
??x
Human reproduction occurs when a sperm from a male fertilizes an egg from a female. This fusion results in the creation of a zygote which may implant itself in the uterus and potentially develop into a fetus.
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 10  General Science and Life Science   209Damage control through the   integumentary system The integumentary system  protects you from getting scuffed up, losing all the water in your body,  ...

chapter_title: Continuing the species through the reproductive system. Digging through Plant Physiology
flashcard_content:
#### Genetic Combination in Reproduction
Genetics play a crucial role in human reproduction, combining genetic material to form new life. DNA within reproductive cells (sperm and eggs) combines during fertilization to create a unique set of chromosomes for the offspring.
:p How do genetics contribute to human reproduction?
??x
Genetics contribute to human reproduction through the combination of DNA from both parents. When a sperm cell fuses with an egg, their genetic material combines to form a new individual with a unique set of chromosomes.
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 10  General Science and Life Science   209Damage control through the   integumentary system The integumentary system  protects you from getting scuffed up, losing all the water in your body,  ...

chapter_title: Continuing the species through the reproductive system. Digging through Plant Physiology
flashcard_content:
#### Nutritional Requirements for Body Functioning
Your body needs a balanced intake of carbohydrates, fats, fiber, minerals, and proteins to function optimally. Carbohydrates provide energy, fats are essential but come in different types (saturated, monounsaturated, polyunsaturated), fiber aids digestion, minerals like iron, calcium, and potassium support various bodily functions, and protein is vital for growth, maintenance, and repair.
:p What nutrients does the body need to function properly?
??x
The body needs carbohydrates, fats, fiber, minerals, and proteins to function properly. Carbohydrates provide energy from starches and sugars, fats are essential but come in different types (saturated, monounsaturated, polyunsaturated), fiber aids digestion, minerals like iron, calcium, and potassium support various bodily functions, and protein is vital for growth, maintenance, and repair.
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 10  General Science and Life Science   209Damage control through the   integumentary system The integumentary system  protects you from getting scuffed up, losing all the water in your body,  ...

chapter_title: Continuing the species through the reproductive system. Digging through Plant Physiology
flashcard_content:
#### Types of Fats
Fats are crucial for energy provision. There are three main categories: saturated fats (found in meat, shellfish, eggs, dairy), monounsaturated fats (olive oil, avocados, nuts), and polyunsaturated fats (vegetable oils, walnuts, some fish). Polyunsaturated fats are necessary but cannot be produced by the body.
:p What are the different types of fats and their sources?
??x
There are three main types of fats: 
- Saturated fats found in meat, shellfish, eggs, dairy. 
- Monounsaturated fats from olive oil, avocados, nuts.
- Polyunsaturated fats from vegetable oils, walnuts, some fish.

Polyunsaturated fats are required but cannot be produced by the body and must be obtained through diet.
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 10  General Science and Life Science   209Damage control through the   integumentary system The integumentary system  protects you from getting scuffed up, losing all the water in your body,  ...

chapter_title: Continuing the species through the reproductive system. Digging through Plant Physiology
flashcard_content:
#### Fiber's Role in Digestion
Fiber is essential for maintaining a healthy digestive system. Sources of fiber include leafy green vegetables, beans, potatoes, and fruits. Adequate fiber intake helps with waste removal and overall bowel health.
:p What role does fiber play in the body?
??x
Fiber plays a crucial role in digestion by aiding in the elimination of waste products from the body. Good sources of fiber include leafy green vegetables, beans, potatoes, and fruits. Fiber ensures that food moves smoothly through the digestive tract, supporting overall bowel health.
x??

---

chapter_title: Types of plants. Where plant processes take place
flashcard_content:
---
#### Vitamins for Various Bodily Functions
Background context: The human body requires essential vitamins to perform various functions such as blood clotting, processing food, and regulating hormones. These can typically be obtained from fruits, vegetables, and sunlight.

:p What are some bodily functions that require vitamins?
??x
Vitamins play a crucial role in several bodily functions including:
- Blood clotting: Vitamin K is essential for the synthesis of proteins required for blood coagulation.
- Processing food: B-complex vitamins (B1, B2, B3, B6, B9, and B12) aid in energy metabolism by helping convert macronutrients into usable energy.
- Regulating hormones: Vitamin D is vital for calcium absorption and maintaining bone health, while vitamin E acts as an antioxidant to protect cells from damage.

x??
input_text_excerpt: 210 PART 4  Examining General Science under a Microscope »Vitamins for various bodily functions: You can usually get all the 13 essential vitamins from  fruits, veggies, and the sun. Your body uses th...

chapter_title: Types of plants. Where plant processes take place
flashcard_content:
#### Water and Hydration
Background context: Water is crucial for preventing cell shrinkage and ensuring proper bodily function. The human body loses about four pints of water daily through various processes, necessitating constant hydration.

:p How much water does the human body lose each day?
??x
The human body typically loses approximately 4 pints (about 2 liters) of water per day due to various physiological processes such as sweating, urination, and respiration. It is important to replenish this lost fluid to avoid dehydration, which can lead to symptoms like headaches, cramps, and in severe cases, death.

x??
input_text_excerpt: 210 PART 4  Examining General Science under a Microscope »Vitamins for various bodily functions: You can usually get all the 13 essential vitamins from  fruits, veggies, and the sun. Your body uses th...

chapter_title: Types of plants. Where plant processes take place
flashcard_content:
#### Balanced Military Diet
Background context: During basic training, the military ensures a balanced diet that provides all necessary nutrients for trainees to become fit and efficient fighting machines. Even though taste may be compromised due to busy schedules, nutritional balance is paramount.

:p What does the military ensure in terms of nutrition during basic training?
??x
The military guarantees a nutritionally balanced diet for recruits to support their physical demands during rigorous training. This includes essential vitamins from fruits and vegetables, as well as hydration through drinking water. The goal is to maintain peak physical condition without relying on individual meal choices.

x??
input_text_excerpt: 210 PART 4  Examining General Science under a Microscope »Vitamins for various bodily functions: You can usually get all the 13 essential vitamins from  fruits, veggies, and the sun. Your body uses th...

chapter_title: Types of plants. Where plant processes take place
flashcard_content:
#### Plant Organs
Background context: Plants have organs similar to those in animals but serve different purposes. They typically have two main organ systems: roots for nutrient absorption and anchoring, and shoots (stems, leaves, flowers) that facilitate growth and energy conversion.

:p What are the two main organ systems of plants?
??x
Plants possess two primary organ systems:
- Roots: Absorb water and nutrients from the soil and anchor the plant.
- Shoots: Include stems, leaves, flowers, and seeds. They support the plant above ground, serve as pathways for nutrient transport, capture sunlight, and produce food through photosynthesis.

x??
input_text_excerpt: 210 PART 4  Examining General Science under a Microscope »Vitamins for various bodily functions: You can usually get all the 13 essential vitamins from  fruits, veggies, and the sun. Your body uses th...

chapter_title: Types of plants. Where plant processes take place
flashcard_content:
#### Types of Plants
Background context: Plants are classified into four major groups based on their tissue structure and reproductive methods according to the Linnaean taxonomic system.

:p What are the four main types of plants mentioned in the text?
??x
The four primary types of plants described are:
- Angiosperms: Flowering plants with vascular tissue, producing flowers and seeds. Examples include roses, apple trees.
- Bryophytes: Non-vascular plants that reproduce via spores, such as lichen, liverwort, mosses.
- Ferns: Vascular plants without seeds, reproducing by spores.
- Gymnosperms: Plants with vascular tissue, producing cones and seeds. Examples include Christmas trees and giant sequoias.

x??
input_text_excerpt: 210 PART 4  Examining General Science under a Microscope »Vitamins for various bodily functions: You can usually get all the 13 essential vitamins from  fruits, veggies, and the sun. Your body uses th...

chapter_title: Types of plants. Where plant processes take place
flashcard_content:
#### Plant Processes
Background context: Plants sustain life through various processes including nutrient absorption from the soil, energy capture from sunlight, and carbon dioxide intake. Photosynthesis is a key process involving two stages: light-dependent reactions and the Calvin cycle.

:p What are the two main stages of photosynthesis?
??x
Photosynthesis in plants involves two primary stages:
- Light-dependent reactions: Chlorophyll and other pigments absorb sunlight energy to split water molecules into hydrogen and oxygen. The hydrogen forms glucose through chemical reactions.
- The Calvin cycle: A series of chemical reactions that occur after capturing sunlight, converting the absorbed carbon dioxide into glucose.

x??
input_text_excerpt: 210 PART 4  Examining General Science under a Microscope »Vitamins for various bodily functions: You can usually get all the 13 essential vitamins from  fruits, veggies, and the sun. Your body uses th...

chapter_title: Types of plants. Where plant processes take place
flashcard_content:
#### Carbon in Plant Processes
Background context: Carbon is fundamental for plant life as it forms the backbone of essential molecules such as DNA and proteins. It bonds with other elements to create long chains and rings necessary for plant growth.

:p Why is carbon so important for plants?
??x
Carbon is critical for plants because:
- It forms the basic structure of many organic compounds.
- Without carbon, complex structures like DNA would be impossible.
- Carbon can bond with itself to form long chains and rings, essential for constructing vital biological molecules such as proteins.

x??
---
input_text_excerpt: 210 PART 4  Examining General Science under a Microscope »Vitamins for various bodily functions: You can usually get all the 13 essential vitamins from  fruits, veggies, and the sun. Your body uses th...

chapter_title: Plant reproduction. Thinking Small A Look at Cells. Swimming in the Gene Pool Genetics
flashcard_title: Plant Reproduction: Sexual and Asexual Methods
flashcard_content:
#### Plant Reproduction: Sexual and Asexual Methods

Background context explaining the concept of plant reproduction, including both sexual and asexual methods. Plants can reproduce sexually by combining cells with half the DNA to form new whole cells, or asexually by one cell splitting into two identical cells.

:p What are the two primary ways plants can reproduce?
??x
Plants can reproduce either sexually, where two cells carrying half the DNA join to form a new whole cell, or asexually, where a single cell splits into two identical cells.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 212 PART 4  Examining General Science under a MicroscopePlant reproduction Plants, like all other organisms, need to reproduce. They can do so sexually (when two cells car- rying half the DNA necessar...

chapter_title: Plant reproduction. Thinking Small A Look at Cells. Swimming in the Gene Pool Genetics
flashcard_content:
#### Plant Reproduction: Angiosperms and Gymnosperms

Background context explaining the difference between angiosperms and gymnosperms. Angiosperms produce flowers that contain stigma (which produces pollen) and carpels (which catch pollen), while gymnosperms produce seeds directly on cone scales.

:p What are angiosperms known for in their reproduction process?
??x
Angiosperms are known for producing flowers, which contain the stigma (that produces pollen) and carpels (that catch pollen). This process often involves pollination by insects, birds, or wind.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 212 PART 4  Examining General Science under a MicroscopePlant reproduction Plants, like all other organisms, need to reproduce. They can do so sexually (when two cells car- rying half the DNA necessar...

chapter_title: Plant reproduction. Thinking Small A Look at Cells. Swimming in the Gene Pool Genetics
flashcard_content:
#### Plant Reproduction: Bryophytes and Ferns

Background context explaining bryophytes and ferns. These are considered primitive plants that reproduce through spores rather than seeds.

:p How do bryophytes and ferns reproduce?
??x
Bryophytes and ferns reproduce through spores, which contain both male and female reproductive organs. Fertilization occurs before the plant releases a spore.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 212 PART 4  Examining General Science under a MicroscopePlant reproduction Plants, like all other organisms, need to reproduce. They can do so sexually (when two cells car- rying half the DNA necessar...

chapter_title: Plant reproduction. Thinking Small A Look at Cells. Swimming in the Gene Pool Genetics
flashcard_content:
#### Cell Structure: Common Features

Background context explaining that nearly all cells share certain common features such as a nucleus, cytoplasm, cell membrane, and ribosomes.

:p What are the four things most cells have in common?
??x
Most cells have a nucleus (controlling cellular activity), cytoplasm (a gel-like substance containing chemicals for life processes), cell membrane (protecting the nucleus and cytoplasm), and ribosomes (manufacturing proteins).
x??
input_text_excerpt: 212 PART 4  Examining General Science under a MicroscopePlant reproduction Plants, like all other organisms, need to reproduce. They can do so sexually (when two cells car- rying half the DNA necessar...

chapter_title: Plant reproduction. Thinking Small A Look at Cells. Swimming in the Gene Pool Genetics
flashcard_title: Cell Structure: Bacteria vs. Other Cells
flashcard_content:
#### Cell Structure: Bacteria vs. Other Cells

Background context explaining that bacteria are prokaryotes, lacking a nuclear envelope but having genetic material in the cytoplasm.

:p How do bacterial cells differ from other cell types?
??x
Bacterial cells differ as they are prokaryotes without a nuclear membrane; their genetic material is located in the cytoplasm.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 212 PART 4  Examining General Science under a MicroscopePlant reproduction Plants, like all other organisms, need to reproduce. They can do so sexually (when two cells car- rying half the DNA necessar...

chapter_title: Plant reproduction. Thinking Small A Look at Cells. Swimming in the Gene Pool Genetics
flashcard_content:
#### Plant Cells vs. Animal Cells

Background context explaining key differences between plant and animal cells, including cell walls, vacuoles, chloroplasts, centrioles, and lysosomes.

:p How do plant cells differ from animal cells?
??x
Plant cells have a firm cell wall for support and protection, larger vacuoles, and chloroplasts with chlorophyll. They lack centrioles and lysosomes found in many animal cells.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 212 PART 4  Examining General Science under a MicroscopePlant reproduction Plants, like all other organisms, need to reproduce. They can do so sexually (when two cells car- rying half the DNA necessar...

chapter_title: Plant reproduction. Thinking Small A Look at Cells. Swimming in the Gene Pool Genetics
flashcard_content:
#### Cell Processes: Metabolism

Background context explaining metabolism as the chemical processes necessary to maintain life within a cell.

:p What is metabolism?
??x
Metabolism refers to the various chemical processes that occur within a cell, essential for maintaining its life functions.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 212 PART 4  Examining General Science under a MicroscopePlant reproduction Plants, like all other organisms, need to reproduce. They can do so sexually (when two cells car- rying half the DNA necessar...

chapter_title: Plant reproduction. Thinking Small A Look at Cells. Swimming in the Gene Pool Genetics
flashcard_content:
#### Cell Processes: Osmosis

Background context explaining osmosis as the movement of liquid through the cell membrane and how it helps regulate water balance in cells.

:p What is osmosis?
??x
Osmosis is the process by which liquids move across a semipermeable membrane from an area of higher concentration to lower concentration, primarily regulating water flow into and out of cells.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 212 PART 4  Examining General Science under a MicroscopePlant reproduction Plants, like all other organisms, need to reproduce. They can do so sexually (when two cells car- rying half the DNA necessar...

chapter_title: Copying genes. Knowing which genes get passed down the family line
flashcard_content:
#### Phagocytosis
Phagocytosis is a process where cells engulf and internalize particles from their external environment. This mechanism is crucial for immune responses, cellular debris removal, and nutrient acquisition.

:p What is phagocytosis?
??x
Phagocytosis involves the cell surrounding and internalizing solid particles or organisms from its exterior to process them within the cell.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 214 PART 4  Examining General Science under a Microscope »Phagocytosis: Acquisition of particles of material from outside the cell; it’s accomplished by  surrounding the particles and passing them thr...

chapter_title: Copying genes. Knowing which genes get passed down the family line
flashcard_content:
#### Photosynthesis
Photosynthesis converts light energy into chemical energy that can be utilized by cells. This process primarily occurs in plants, algae, and certain bacteria.

:p What is photosynthesis?
??x
Photosynthesis is a biochemical process where organisms convert sunlight into chemical energy stored in organic molecules like glucose.
x??

chapter_title: Copying genes. Knowing which genes get passed down the family line
flashcard_content:
#### Cellular Respiration
Cellular respiration is the metabolic process by which cells convert nutrients (like sugars) into energy. This process yields adenosine triphosphate (ATP), which powers cellular activities.

:p What is cellular respiration?
??x
Cellular respiration transforms biochemical energy from nutrients into products that fuel cell activity, producing ATP as a primary source of energy.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 214 PART 4  Examining General Science under a Microscope »Phagocytosis: Acquisition of particles of material from outside the cell; it’s accomplished by  surrounding the particles and passing them thr...

chapter_title: Copying genes. Knowing which genes get passed down the family line
flashcard_content:
#### Genetics Overview
Genetics studies the transmission and variation of traits from parents to offspring. Understanding genetics helps in pinpointing disease causes and developing treatments.

:p What is genetics?
??x
Genetics involves studying how traits are passed from parents to offspring and what happens when genetic processes go awry, aiding in disease identification and treatment.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 214 PART 4  Examining General Science under a Microscope »Phagocytosis: Acquisition of particles of material from outside the cell; it’s accomplished by  surrounding the particles and passing them thr...

chapter_title: Copying genes. Knowing which genes get passed down the family line
flashcard_content:
#### Mitosis Process
Mitosis is a type of cell division that results in two identical daughter cells with the same number of chromosomes as the parent cell.

:p What is mitosis?
??x
Mitosis is a form of cell division where the nucleus replicates to create two genetically identical daughter cells, each containing the same set of chromosomes.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 214 PART 4  Examining General Science under a Microscope »Phagocytosis: Acquisition of particles of material from outside the cell; it’s accomplished by  surrounding the particles and passing them thr...

chapter_title: Copying genes. Knowing which genes get passed down the family line
flashcard_content:
#### Meiosis Process
Meiosis is a specialized type of cell division that results in four non-identical daughter cells with half the number of chromosomes as the parent cell.

:p What is meiosis?
??x
Meiosis is a process where one cell divides into four, each containing only half the number of chromosomes to ensure proper fertilization.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 214 PART 4  Examining General Science under a Microscope »Phagocytosis: Acquisition of particles of material from outside the cell; it’s accomplished by  surrounding the particles and passing them thr...

chapter_title: Copying genes. Knowing which genes get passed down the family line
flashcard_content:
#### Chromosome Distribution in Humans
Humans have 46 chromosomes, typically arranged in 23 pairs. Each parent contributes one chromosome per pair.

:p How are human chromosomes distributed?
??x
In humans, there are 23 pairs of chromosomes (46 total). The mother and father each contribute one chromosome to the offspring, resulting in a balanced set.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 214 PART 4  Examining General Science under a Microscope »Phagocytosis: Acquisition of particles of material from outside the cell; it’s accomplished by  surrounding the particles and passing them thr...

chapter_title: Copying genes. Knowing which genes get passed down the family line
flashcard_content:
#### Gene Copying Process
During cell division for tissue formation, cells copy their genetic material. This occurs through mitosis or meiosis depending on whether it is somatic or germ cells.

:p How do cells copy their genetic material?
??x
Cells copy their genetic material using either mitosis (for somatic cells) or meiosis (for germ cells), ensuring proper chromosome distribution.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 214 PART 4  Examining General Science under a Microscope »Phagocytosis: Acquisition of particles of material from outside the cell; it’s accomplished by  surrounding the particles and passing them thr...

chapter_title: Copying genes. Knowing which genes get passed down the family line
flashcard_content:
#### Genetic Differences and Disorders
Errors in cell division can lead to genetic differences, causing issues like Down syndrome.

:p What causes genetic disorders?
??x
Genetic disorders often result from errors during cell division, such as the incorrect number of chromosomes (e.g., 47 instead of 46 for Down syndrome).
x??
input_text_excerpt: 214 PART 4  Examining General Science under a Microscope »Phagocytosis: Acquisition of particles of material from outside the cell; it’s accomplished by  surrounding the particles and passing them thr...

chapter_title: Copying genes. Knowing which genes get passed down the family line
flashcard_content:
#### Determining Sex Genetically
Sex is determined by a pair of sex chromosomes. Females have XX and males have XY.

:p How are sex chromosomes involved in determining gender?
??x
The sex chromosomes determine whether an individual is male or female, with females having two X chromosomes (XX) and males having one X and one Y (XY).
x??

---

flashcard_content:
#### Cell Nucleus Control Center
Background context explaining that a cell nucleus often serves as the control center, containing most of the cell’s genetic material. This is crucial for gene regulation and overall cellular function.

:p What is the cell nucleus often referred to as?
??x
The cell nucleus is often referred to as the control center because it houses the majority of the cell's genetic material (DNA) and plays a key role in regulating gene expression and replication.
x??

#### Human Circulatory System Function
Background context explaining that the human circulatory system is responsible for moving oxygenated blood throughout the body. This system includes components like arteries, veins, and capillaries to facilitate this process.

:p What does the human circulatory system primarily do?
??x
The human circulatory system primarily moves oxygenated blood throughout the body, delivering nutrients and removing waste products.
x??

#### Protein Sources
Background context explaining that proteins are essential for various bodily functions and come from different sources like beans, meat, and eggs. Water is not a source of protein.

:p Which of the following is **not** a source of protein?
??x
Water is not a source of protein, making it the correct answer.
x??

#### Animal Classification: Herbivores
Background context explaining that herbivores are animals that eat only plants. This classification contrasts with other types like carnivores and omnivores.

:p Which type of animal eats only plants?
??x
Animals that eat only plants are called herbivores, so the correct answer is "herbivores."
x??

#### Nasal Cavity System
Background context explaining that the nasal cavity is part of the respiratory system, where air enters and travels to the lungs. This involves other components like the nose, trachea.

:p Which system does the nasal cavity belong to?
??x
The nasal cavity belongs to the respiratory system.

#### Gram as a Unit of Measurement
Background context explaining that grams are units used in the metric system for measuring mass, not liquid volume or distance.

:p What is the gram unit of?
??x
Grams are a unit of mass in the metric system.

#### Scientific Method: First Step
Background context explaining that the scientific method begins with making observations before asking questions and forming hypotheses. This step is fundamental for starting any scientific inquiry.

:p What is the first step in the scientific method?
??x
The first step in the scientific method is to make observations.

Background context explaining that "sapiens" in the term Homo sapiens refers to the species. This involves understanding the hierarchical classification of living organisms.

:p What does "sapiens" describe in Homo sapiens?

The word "sapiens" describes the species in the term Homo sapiens.

Background context explaining that most cells reproduce through mitosis, which involves dividing into two identical daughter cells. Meiosis is a different process involving four separate cells.

:p How do most cells usually reproduce?

Most cells reproduce by mitosis, the process of dividing into two separate cells with identical DNA.

flashcard_content:
#### Hinge Joints in the Human Body
Background context explaining that hinge joints allow for limited movement in one direction, like the elbow or knee. These joints are distinct from other types such as pivot or ball-and-socket.

:p Where would you find a hinge joint in the human body?
??x
A hinge joint is found at the elbow.

chapter_title: Chemistry Not Blowing Up the Lab
flashcard_content:
#### Unearthing Elements
Background context explaining the concept of elements. Elements are pure substances made up of only one type of atom, each with a unique number of protons in its nucleus. The periodic table organizes these elements based on their atomic numbers and chemical properties.

The Periodic Table: 
- Each element is represented by a symbol (e.g., H for Hydrogen).
- Elements are organized into periods (rows) and groups (columns).

:p What are the defining characteristics of an element?
??x
An element is defined by its unique number of protons in the nucleus, which determines its atomic number. This number also dictates how it interacts with other elements to form compounds.
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 11  Physical Sciences   219 Physical Sciences Brushing up on your chemistry and physics knowledge for the General Science subtest on the  ASVAB is essential if you want to snag a good score fo...

chapter_title: Chemistry Not Blowing Up the Lab
flashcard_content:
#### Compounding Chemistry Facts
Background context: Chemical compounds consist of two or more different atoms bonded together in fixed ratios. The simplest unit of a compound is a molecule.

Chemical Bonding: 
- Ionic bonds involve the transfer of electrons between atoms (resulting in ions).
- Covalent bonds involve sharing electrons.
- Molecular compounds form when non-metal atoms share electrons to achieve stability.

:p What are the two main types of chemical bonds?
??x
The two main types of chemical bonds are ionic and covalent. Ionic bonds involve the transfer of electrons between atoms, while covalent bonds involve the sharing of electrons.
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 11  Physical Sciences   219 Physical Sciences Brushing up on your chemistry and physics knowledge for the General Science subtest on the  ASVAB is essential if you want to snag a good score fo...

chapter_title: Chemistry Not Blowing Up the Lab
flashcard_title: Seeing what’s up with SI Units
flashcard_content:
#### Seeing what’s up with SI Units
Background context: The International System of Units (SI) is a set of units used in science for measuring length, mass, time, and other physical quantities. It includes base units such as meters, kilograms, seconds, and derived units like liters.

SI Base Units:
- Length: meter (m)
- Mass: kilogram (kg)
- Time: second (s)

:p What are the three base SI units for measuring length, mass, and time?
??x
The three base SI units are:
- Length: meter (m)
- Mass: kilogram (kg)
- Time: second (s)
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 11  Physical Sciences   219 Physical Sciences Brushing up on your chemistry and physics knowledge for the General Science subtest on the  ASVAB is essential if you want to snag a good score fo...

chapter_title: Chemistry Not Blowing Up the Lab
flashcard_content:
#### Studying Matter, Mass, and Motion
Background context: Matter is anything that has mass and takes up space. The study of matter includes understanding its physical properties such as density, volume, and mass.

Matter Properties:
- Density = Mass / Volume
- Volume can be calculated using length measurements (l x w x h).

:p What is the formula for calculating density?
??x
Density is calculated by dividing the mass of an object by its volume: 
\[ \text{Density} = \frac{\text{Mass}}{\text{Volume}} \]
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 11  Physical Sciences   219 Physical Sciences Brushing up on your chemistry and physics knowledge for the General Science subtest on the  ASVAB is essential if you want to snag a good score fo...

chapter_title: Chemistry Not Blowing Up the Lab
flashcard_title: Finding out about Physics Topics like Frequencies and Magnets
flashcard_content:
#### Finding out about Physics Topics like Frequencies and Magnets
Background context: In physics, frequency refers to how often a periodic event occurs in one second. The unit of frequency is Hertz (Hz). Magnets have poles (north and south) and can interact with other magnetic fields.

Frequency Calculation:
- Frequency = Number of cycles / Time

:p What is the unit for measuring frequency?
??x
The unit for measuring frequency is Hertz (Hz), which represents how many cycles occur in one second.
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 11  Physical Sciences   219 Physical Sciences Brushing up on your chemistry and physics knowledge for the General Science subtest on the  ASVAB is essential if you want to snag a good score fo...

chapter_title: Chemistry Not Blowing Up the Lab
flashcard_content:
#### Magnetism Basics
Background context: Magnets have north and south poles, and they interact with other magnetic fields. Opposite poles attract each other, while like poles repel.

Magnetic Poles:
- North pole of one magnet attracts the south pole of another magnet.
- Two north or two south poles repel each other.

:p What happens when you place a north pole near another north pole?
??x
When you place a north pole near another north pole, they repel each other. This is because like magnetic poles repel.
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 11  Physical Sciences   219 Physical Sciences Brushing up on your chemistry and physics knowledge for the General Science subtest on the  ASVAB is essential if you want to snag a good score fo...

chapter_title: Chemistry Not Blowing Up the Lab
flashcard_content:
#### Periodic Table Organization
Background context: The periodic table organizes elements based on their atomic number and chemical properties. Elements are grouped into periods (rows) and groups (columns).

Periodic Table Structure:
- Periods go across the top, representing different energy levels of electrons.
- Groups go down the side, sharing similar chemical properties.

:p What do rows in the periodic table represent?
??x
Rows in the periodic table represent different energy levels of electrons. Each row corresponds to a new principal energy level or shell.
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 11  Physical Sciences   219 Physical Sciences Brushing up on your chemistry and physics knowledge for the General Science subtest on the  ASVAB is essential if you want to snag a good score fo...

chapter_title: Chemistry Not Blowing Up the Lab
flashcard_content:
#### Chemical Bonding Types
Background context: There are several types of chemical bonds, including ionic and covalent bonds. Ionic bonds involve the transfer of electrons between atoms, while covalent bonds involve sharing electrons.

:p What is an example of a covalent bond?
??x
An example of a covalent bond is the bond formed between two hydrogen atoms to create a molecule of dihydrogen (H₂). In this bond, each hydrogen atom shares its single electron with the other, resulting in a stable molecule.
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 11  Physical Sciences   219 Physical Sciences Brushing up on your chemistry and physics knowledge for the General Science subtest on the  ASVAB is essential if you want to snag a good score fo...

chapter_title: Chemistry Not Blowing Up the Lab
flashcard_content:
#### SI Units for Volume
Background context: Derived units in the SI system include those used to measure volume. One common derived unit is the liter (L), which is equivalent to one cubic decimeter (dm³).

:p What is another name for 1 liter in terms of cubic meters?
??x
Another name for 1 liter in terms of cubic meters is \(0.001\) m³, since \(1 \text{ L} = 1 \text{ dm}^3 = 0.001 \text{ m}^3\).
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 11  Physical Sciences   219 Physical Sciences Brushing up on your chemistry and physics knowledge for the General Science subtest on the  ASVAB is essential if you want to snag a good score fo...

chapter_title: Chemistry Not Blowing Up the Lab
flashcard_content:
#### Density Calculation Example
Background context: The formula for density is used to determine how tightly packed the particles of a substance are.

:p How would you calculate the density of an object with mass 5 kg and volume 2 m³?
??x
To calculate the density, use the formula:
\[ \text{Density} = \frac{\text{Mass}}{\text{Volume}} \]
Given: Mass = 5 kg, Volume = 2 m³.

\[
\text{Density} = \frac{5 \text{ kg}}{2 \text{ m}^3} = 2.5 \text{ kg/m}^3
\]
x??

chapter_title: Chemistry Not Blowing Up the Lab
flashcard_content:
#### Frequency in Physics
Background context: Frequency is the number of cycles or occurrences per unit time, typically measured in Hertz (Hz).

:p What does 1 Hz represent?
??x
1 Hz represents one cycle per second.
x??

---

chapter_title: Understanding the elements my dear Watson
flashcard_content:
---
#### Elements and Matter
Background context: Chemists study matter, which includes everything that has mass and takes up space. The basic substances (building blocks) of matter are called elements.

:p What are elements, and how do chemists describe matter?
??x
Elements are fundamental substances that cannot be broken down into simpler substances by chemical means. They make up all matter. Chemists describe matter based on its properties and composition.
x??

chapter_title: Understanding the elements my dear Watson
flashcard_content:
#### Macroscopic vs Microscopic View
Background context: Chemists observe the world in two ways: macroscopically (the large-scale view of everything you can see) and microscopically (a much smaller level, where gas particles interact and atoms bind).

:p How do chemists differentiate between macroscopic and microscopic views?
??x
Macroscopic refers to the observable properties of substances at a scale that can be seen with the naked eye or simple instruments. Microscopic refers to the detailed interactions at an atomic or molecular level, which require microscopes for visualization.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 220  PART 4  Examining General Science under a MicroscopeChemistry: Not Blowing Up the Lab Chemists study matter, and everything that has mass and takes up space — including your old  Chevy that’s up ...

chapter_title: Understanding the elements my dear Watson
flashcard_content:
#### Scientific Method in Chemistry
Background context: Chemists follow the scientific method to study matter and develop new theories and compounds. This involves making observations, forming hypotheses, testing them through experiments, analyzing results, and drawing conclusions.

:p What is the scientific method used by chemists?
??x
The scientific method includes steps such as observation, hypothesis formulation, experimentation, data analysis, and conclusion drawing. It helps ensure that findings are reliable and valid.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 220  PART 4  Examining General Science under a MicroscopeChemistry: Not Blowing Up the Lab Chemists study matter, and everything that has mass and takes up space — including your old  Chevy that’s up ...

chapter_title: Understanding the elements my dear Watson
flashcard_content:
#### Everyday Chemistry Examples
Background context: Everything in the world is made from chemical elements, including common household items like cleaning supplies, clothing materials, and food.

:p What role does chemistry play in everyday objects?
??x
Chemistry plays a crucial role in everyday life. For example, chemicals are engineered to improve products such as nylon fabrics, polycarbonate plastics used in glasses, and even the cleaning agents in your kitchen.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 220  PART 4  Examining General Science under a MicroscopeChemistry: Not Blowing Up the Lab Chemists study matter, and everything that has mass and takes up space — including your old  Chevy that’s up ...

chapter_title: Understanding the elements my dear Watson
flashcard_content:
#### Dihydrogen Oxide Example
Background context: The chemical dihydrogen oxide is water (H2O), which covers about 71% of Earth's surface. Even though it's familiar, it remains a significant element studied by chemists.

:p What is the significance of dihydrogen oxide in chemistry?
??x
Dihydrogen oxide, or H2O, is fundamental to life on Earth and is extensively studied by chemists for its properties and interactions with other substances. Its presence in large quantities makes it crucial for understanding environmental and biological processes.
x??

chapter_title: Compounds mixtures and reactions When elements get together
flashcard_title: Boiling Point and State Changes of Water
flashcard_content:
---
#### Boiling Point and State Changes of Water
When you're making spaghetti, boiling water is used to change the pasta from a solid state into a more softened form. The temperature of water increases as it absorbs heat until it reaches its boiling point at 100 degrees Celsius (212 degrees Fahrenheit) under normal atmospheric pressure.

The transition of water from liquid to gas involves the process of evaporation, where molecules gain enough energy to break free and enter the gaseous state. This temperature remains constant during the phase change because all the heat energy is used for changing states rather than raising the temperature further.

:p What is the boiling point of water at sea level?
??x
The boiling point of water at sea level is 100 degrees Celsius or 212 degrees Fahrenheit.
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 11   Physical Sciences   223Boiling and freezing When you’re making spaghetti for dinner, the first thing you do is boil a pot of water so you have  an environment that’s hot enough to change ...

chapter_title: Compounds mixtures and reactions When elements get together
flashcard_content:
#### Condensation and Phase Change
Condensation is a phase change where a gas transforms into a liquid. This happens when cooler surfaces attract water vapor in the air, causing it to condense into droplets. Examples of this include fogging glasses, dew on grass, or a cold drink sweating.

:p What is an example of condensation?
??x
An example of condensation is seeing dew on grass in the morning.
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 11   Physical Sciences   223Boiling and freezing When you’re making spaghetti for dinner, the first thing you do is boil a pot of water so you have  an environment that’s hot enough to change ...

chapter_title: Compounds mixtures and reactions When elements get together
flashcard_content:
#### Freezing and Deposition
Freezing occurs when heat is removed from a substance, slowing down molecular motion until it solidifies. The freezing point for water is -0°C or 32°F at sea level.

Deposition is the reverse of sublimation; it’s when a gas turns directly into a solid without going through a liquid phase. For instance, dry ice (solid CO2) sublimes to form carbon dioxide gas but can create a visible white cloud due to condensation of water vapor in the air as it cools.

:p What is deposition?
??x
Deposition is the process where a substance changes directly from a gaseous state to a solid state without passing through the liquid phase.
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 11   Physical Sciences   223Boiling and freezing When you’re making spaghetti for dinner, the first thing you do is boil a pot of water so you have  an environment that’s hot enough to change ...

chapter_title: Compounds mixtures and reactions When elements get together
flashcard_content:
#### Sublimation and Dry Ice
Sublimation happens when a substance transitions directly from a solid to a gas, bypassing the liquid stage. An example of this is dry ice (solid CO2) turning into carbon dioxide gas.

The process of sublimation can create dramatic effects like smoke or fog in magic shows or nightclubs due to the rapid cooling and evaporation producing visible clouds.

:p What substance is commonly used for creating smoke or fog effects through sublimation?
??x
Dry ice, which is solid carbon dioxide, is commonly used for creating smoke or fog effects.
x??
input_text_excerpt: CHAPTER 11   Physical Sciences   223Boiling and freezing When you’re making spaghetti for dinner, the first thing you do is boil a pot of water so you have  an environment that’s hot enough to change ...

chapter_title: Compounds mixtures and reactions When elements get together
flashcard_content:
#### States of Matter Overview
The text describes how different states of matter (solid, liquid, gas) can change due to temperature and pressure changes. Molecules in each state move differently; solids have the least movement, liquids more, and gases the most.

:p How do molecules behave differently in solid, liquid, and gaseous states?
??x
In a solid state, molecules vibrate but stay in fixed positions relative to each other. In a liquid state, molecules can flow past one another with some freedom of motion. In a gas state, molecules move very rapidly and spread out as far apart as they can.
x??

---

chapter_title: Mixtures Physical combinations of pure substances
flashcard_title: Compounds: Elements Joining by Chemical Bonds
flashcard_content:
---
#### Compounds: Elements Joining by Chemical Bonds
Compounds are formed when elements combine through chemical bonds at specific ratios. For instance, water (H2O) is a compound where hydrogen and oxygen combine in a ratio of 2 atoms of hydrogen to every 1 atom of oxygen.

:p How do elements form compounds?
??x
Elements form compounds by combining with each other in specific ratios through chemical bonds. This means that for water (H2O), two hydrogen atoms bond with one oxygen atom, adhering to the strict stoichiometric ratio.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 224  PART 4  Examining General Science under a MicroscopeCompounds, mixtures, and reactions: When  elements get together Elements that combine can join together in specific ratios, mix and mingle in d...

chapter_title: Mixtures Physical combinations of pure substances
flashcard_content:
#### Reading Chemical Formulas: Basic Structure
Chemical formulas are written as shorthand expressions of molecules and compounds. A formula includes the elemental symbols and subscripts indicating the number of atoms in a molecule. For example, H2O indicates two hydrogen atoms bonding with one oxygen atom.

:p What do subscripts in chemical formulas represent?
??x
Subscripts in chemical formulas indicate the number of atoms of each element present in a single molecule. In H2O, the subscript 2 means there are two hydrogen atoms, and the absence of a subscript after O indicates there is only one oxygen atom.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 224  PART 4  Examining General Science under a MicroscopeCompounds, mixtures, and reactions: When  elements get together Elements that combine can join together in specific ratios, mix and mingle in d...

chapter_title: Mixtures Physical combinations of pure substances
flashcard_title: Reading Chemical Formulas: Number of Molecules
flashcard_content:
#### Reading Chemical Formulas: Number of Molecules
Chemical formulas also include numerical coefficients that indicate how many molecules or units of a compound you have. For example, "5He" denotes five individual helium atoms.

:p How do you represent multiple molecules in chemical formulas?
??x
To represent multiple molecules in a formula, place the number before the molecule's elemental symbol. So, "5He" signifies five helium atoms.
x??
input_text_excerpt: 224  PART 4  Examining General Science under a MicroscopeCompounds, mixtures, and reactions: When  elements get together Elements that combine can join together in specific ratios, mix and mingle in d...

chapter_title: Mixtures Physical combinations of pure substances
flashcard_content:
#### Reading Complex Formulas with Brackets
Some complex formulas use brackets to group elements together before adding subscripts. For instance, AgNO3 includes brackets around NO3, indicating that this is a single unit.

:p What do brackets in chemical formulas indicate?
??x
Brackets in chemical formulas represent groups of atoms that are considered as one unit. In AgNO3, the bracketed NO3 group means that the nitrogen and three oxygen atoms form a single entity.
x??

---
#### Chemical Formulas and Functional Groups
Background context: A chemical formula represents the types and numbers of atoms in a molecule. Functional groups are specific clusters of atoms with distinct properties, often denoted by subscripts.

:p What is the significance of functional groups in understanding chemical formulas?
??x
Functional groups are essential because they help identify the type of reaction a compound might undergo based on its structure. For example, knowing that a compound contains an NO3 group can tell us about its reactivity or potential uses.
x??

flashcard_content:
#### Sugar's Molecular Formula
Background context: The molecular formula for sugar is CHO12 22 11 (simplified to C12H22O11). This indicates the types and number of atoms in each molecule.

:p What does the molecular formula C12H22O11 tell us about sugar?
??x
The formula tells us that each molecule of sugar contains 12 carbon atoms, 22 hydrogen atoms, and 11 oxygen atoms. These elements are essential for sugar's unique properties and taste.
x??

flashcard_content:
#### Acetone’s Chemical Makeup
Background context: Acetone (CH3COCH3) is a compound used in various non-food applications such as paint remover and rubber cement. It has a distinct molecular structure.

:p What is the chemical makeup of acetone, and why might it be unsuitable for coffee?
??x
Acetone’s chemical makeup is CH3COCH3 (or CH3OCH3). It would make the coffee taste very unpleasant and potentially toxic due to its strong and unpleasant odor and taste.
x??

flashcard_content:
#### Mixtures in Chemistry
Background context: A mixture consists of pure substances combined physically without a constant composition. Each component retains its individual chemical characteristics.

:p How do mixtures differ from compounds, and why does bread taste different when made by two bakers?
??x
Mixtures are physical combinations of pure substances with variable compositions, whereas compounds have a fixed ratio of elements. Bread tastes different because each baker uses slightly different proportions or techniques, even though the basic ingredients remain the same.
x??

#### Chemical Reactions Overview
Background context: A chemical reaction involves rearranging atoms within molecules to form new substances. Key concepts include reactants and products.

:p What does a chemical reaction involve in terms of matter?
??x
A chemical reaction involves the reconfiguration of molecular structures, but it does not create or destroy matter. The total mass of reactants equals the total mass of products.
x??

??x
An example is the formation of sodium chloride (table salt) from sodium and chlorine. The balanced equation would be:
\[ 2 \text{Na} + \text{Cl}_2 \rightarrow 2 \text{NaCl} \]

Background context: Combustion reactions typically involve the reaction between carbon and oxygen, often seen in burning processes.

:p Explain how combustion works using an example.
??x
Combustion involves a chemical change where a substance (often involving carbon) reacts with oxygen. For example, when wood burns:
\[ \text{C}_6\text{H}_{10}\text{O}_5 + 6 \text{O}_2 \rightarrow 6 \text{CO}_2 + 5 \text{H}_2\text{O} \]

chapter_title: Physics It Matters and Its Matter. Newtons laws The science of motion
flashcard_content:
#### pH Scale and Acid-Base Chemistry
Background context explaining the concept. Include any relevant formulas or data here.

The pH scale is a logarithmic scale used to specify the acidity or basicity of an aqueous solution. The range extends from 0 (most acidic) to 14 (most basic), with pure water having a neutral pH of 7. A change in whole pH values corresponds to a tenfold change in hydrogen ion concentration.

Formula: \( \text{pH} = -\log_{10}[H^+] \)

Acids give up positively charged hydrogen ions (\(H^+\)) when dissolved in water, while bases give up negatively charged hydroxyl ions (\(OH^-\)). Pure water is neutral (pH 7), and substances that are more acidic or basic move further away from this value.

:p What does the pH scale measure, and what is its range?
??x
The pH scale measures the acidity or basicity of a solution. It ranges from 0 to 14.
x??

chapter_title: Physics It Matters and Its Matter. Newtons laws The science of motion
flashcard_content:
#### Definition of Acids and Bases
Background context explaining the concept. Include any relevant formulas or data here.

Acids are substances that give up \(H^+\) ions when dissolved in water, while bases (also known as alkalis) give up \(OH^-\) ions. Common examples include:

- **Acids**: Vinegar (\(CH_3COOH\)), Orange juice, Sulfuric acid
- **Bases**: Liquid soap, Ammonia, Baking soda

:p What are the defining characteristics of acids and bases in aqueous solutions?
??x
Acids give up \(H^+\) ions when dissolved in water, while bases (alkalis) give up \(OH^-\) ions.
x??

flashcard_title: Definition of pH Scale and Examples
flashcard_content:
#### Definition of pH Scale and Examples
Background context explaining the concept. Include any relevant formulas or data here.

The pH scale ranges from 0 to 14:
- 0 to 6 are acidic solutions; pH 3 is ten times more acidic than pH 4, which is itself ten times more acidic than pH 5.
- 8 to 14 are basic solutions; pH 12 is ten times less basic than pH 11, which in turn is ten times less basic than pH 10.

:p What is the range of the pH scale and how does it work?
??x
The pH scale ranges from 0 to 14. Each whole number below 7 represents a tenfold increase in acidity compared to the next higher number.
x??

chapter_title: Physics It Matters and Its Matter. Newtons laws The science of motion
flashcard_title: SI Units of Measurement for Scientists
flashcard_content:
#### SI Units of Measurement for Scientists
Background context explaining the concept. Include any relevant formulas or data here.

SI (International System of Units) is used globally by scientists for measurements. The basic units are:

- Length: meter (\(m\))
- Mass: kilogram (\(kg\))
- Time: second (\(s\))
- Electric current: ampere (\(A\))
- Thermodynamic temperature: kelvin (\(K\))
- Amount of substance: mole (\(mol\))
- Luminous intensity: candela (\(cd\))

Derived units are combinations of base units. For example, speed is \( \text{meters per second} (m/s) \).

:p What is the International System of Units (SI), and what are some basic SI units?
??x
The International System of Units (SI) is a globally used system for measurements in science. Some basic SI units include:
- Length: meter (\(m\))
- Mass: kilogram (\(kg\))
- Time: second (\(s\))
- Electric current: ampere (\(A\))
- Thermodynamic temperature: kelvin (\(K\))
- Amount of substance: mole (\(mol\))
- Luminous intensity: candela (\(cd\))
x??

chapter_title: Physics It Matters and Its Matter. Newtons laws The science of motion
flashcard_content:
#### Weight vs. Mass
Background context explaining the concept. Include any relevant formulas or data here.

Weight and mass are often confused but are distinct concepts:
- **Weight**: The force exerted by gravity on an object, measured in newtons (N). It changes with gravitational acceleration.
- **Mass**: A measure of matter's inertial property; it remains constant regardless of location.

Formula: \( \text{Weight} = m \times g \)

Where \(m\) is mass and \(g\) is the gravitational acceleration (\(9.81\, m/s^2\) on Earth).

:p How do weight and mass differ in physics?
??x
Weight is the force exerted by gravity on an object, measured in newtons (N), while mass is a measure of matter's inertial property, remaining constant regardless of location.
x??

#### SI Derived Units for Measurements
Background context explaining the concept. Include any relevant formulas or data here.

SI derived units are combinations of base units and include:
- Area: square meter (\(m^2\))
- Volume: cubic meter (\(m^3\))
- Speed and velocity: meters per second (\(m/s\))
- Magnetic field strength: ampere per meter (A/m)
- Luminance: candela per square meter (cd/m²)
- Force: newton (N)
- Energy, work, quantity of heat: joule (J)
- Power: watt (W)
- Electric resistance: ohm (\(\Omega\))
- Electric charge and quantity of electricity: coulomb (C)
- Electric potential difference and electromotive force: volt (V)
- Frequency: hertz (Hz)
- Pressure or stress: pascal (Pa)

:p What are some common SI derived units, and what do they measure?
??x
Common SI derived units include:
- Area: square meter (\(m^2\))
- Volume: cubic meter (\(m^3\))
- Speed and velocity: meters per second (\(m/s\))
- Magnetic field strength: ampere per meter (A/m)

- Force: newton (N)

- Power: watt (W)
- Electric resistance: ohm (\(\Omega\))
- Electric charge and quantity of electricity: coulomb (C)
- Electric potential difference and electromotive force: volt (V)
